citation.article-title: Aurantimonas altamirensis sp. nov., a member of the order Rhizobiales isolated from Altamira Cave
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Aurantimonas altamirensis sp. nov.
Aurantimonas altamirensis [al.ta.mi.ren′sis. N.L. fem. adj. altamirensis referring to Altamira Cave (Cantabria, Spain), where the type strain was isolated].
Cells are non-motile, short rods, 0.9 μm wide and 1.1 μm long on average.
Colonies are about 1 mm in diameter, yellow-coloured, circular, convex and smooth.
Growth occurs between 10 and 40 °C, growing optimally at 28 °C.
The optimum NaCl concentration for growth is 0–20 g NaCl l−1; concentrations up to 50 g l−1 are tolerated.
Peaks in absorption spectra are as defined for the genus.
Chemotaxonomic characteristics are as reported in Table 1.
The predominant fatty acid is C18 : 1ω7c, with significant proportions of C16 : 0, C18 : 1 2-OH, iso-C16 : 0 and C18 : 0; C19 : 0ω8c cyclo is not detected.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 71.8 mol%.
The type strain, strain S21BT (=CECT 7138T=LMG 23375T), was isolated from Altamira Cave (Cantabria, Spain).
